story: Even something as simple as labelling underwear correctly has been made a hash of.Another photo shows how a builder seriously made a mess of installing windows.This outrageous gallery will have you chuckling at some of the funny ways people have mucked up a very simple job.

title: army on standby to handle food and medicines shortages in event of no deal brexit
story: An unnamed minister told the Sunday Times that the military would be drafted in if problems at Britain's ports caused shortages of food, fuel and medicines.They said: "There is a lot of civil contingency planning around the prospect of no deal. That's not frightening the horses, that's just being utterly realistic."A Ministry of Defence source said there had been "no formal request" to supply aid, but acknowledged there is a "blueprint for us supporting the civilian authorities that can be dusted off". The newspaper's report also said there would be a significant impact on the NHS, with the health service moving onto a year-round "winter crisis footing".Prime Minister Theresa May - who has repeatedly said no Brexit deal is better than a bad deal - said earlier this week that the British public should feel "reassurance and comfort" over the government's preparations for a no deal scenario.Mrs May did not deny stockpiling was taking place, but said Downing Street was being "responsible and sensible" whilst simultaneously trying to strike a good deal with Brussels.She told 5 News: "Far from being worried about preparations that we are making, I would say that people should take reassurance and comfort from the fact that the government is saying we are in a negotiation, we are working for a good deal - I believe we can get a good deal - but... because we don't know what the outcome is going to be... let's prepare for every eventuality."This is not just about stockpiling."That concept, what it is, is about making sure that we will be able to continue to do the things that are necessary once we have left the European Union, if we leave without a deal." Chancellor Philip Hammond echoed the PM's words, saying it was "sensible and responsible" for the government to be working in conjunction with industry to stockpile certain vital supplies for the event of no deal.He said: "That's a sensible and responsible thing for a Government to do and large businesses who are importing or exporting large volumes of products or produce will be making contingency plans, and we would encourage them to do so and work closely with them as they are putting those plans together."Health Secretary Matt Hancock told MPs on Tuesday he had asked officials to "work up options for stockpiling" by the pharmaceutical industry, while Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab said the government would be taking steps to make sure there is an "adequate food supply".Ministers said last week that the government would be putting out roughly 70 "technical notices" in the coming weeks, which would lay out the necessary preparations in the UK for exiting without a deal.According to the Sunday Times, these reports will be published all together on one day in late August, rather than throughout the summer, because of fears this would alarm the public.

title: i was told i weighed too much to be anorexic
story: I arrived at the hospital with my mum and sat in the waiting room. It was full of other young people and they didn't look like me. They all looked unhappy, just different, and I couldn't understand why I was there.I entered the room and the doctor diagnosed me with anorexia. I couldn't understand it: anorexics, I thought, were skinny and I certainly wasn't.I accused him of lying and told him to stop making me fat. I wasn't anorexic. Over the next few months things got harder. I felt completely trapped and gradually more out of control.My days were spent obsessively exercising, skipping as many meals as possible and either ending the day with a massive family row or eating dinner really quickly then heading upstairs to make myself sick.I used to sit in my therapy sessions being told that my body was falling apart and I was losing the fat round my organs. But I didn't believe anyone telling me this. I thought they were just jealous I had a best friend who made me feel so good.It spiralled out of control so fast that months after my first appointment at child and adolescent mental health services my heart nearly stopped and I was admitted to a mental health hospital where I spent the next year of my life recovering.It was the hardest year of my life: revisiting past experiences, learning to talk about my feelings and learning to accept that I needed help.After that year in hospital, I had developed a handbook of coping mechanisms - including learning to talk about how I felt, challenging myself around food, and getting rid of all emotions.But my biggest frustration was that people still thought your anorexia must be completely gone if you were a healthy weight.That is not the reality. There is so much more to recovery than gaining physical weight.Recovery isn't always a straight line either. You have to learn what triggers to watch out for, and to be aware if it gets tough again.As we entered in to 2016 I was feeling positive about life. I barely thought about my anorexia and I certainly didn't let her dictate what I did.But after my grandma passed away, anorexia used it as a reason to seduce me. She pulled me in when I was feeling weak and grieving, sucking me closer and closer. After four months of battling with this relentless voice in my head I reached out for help. I got an appointment at my local mental health trust, but because I wasn't underweight there was nothing they could do for me.My story isn't unique. In fact there are countless people who get turned away for not being "thin" enough, or not fitting a specific criteria. It isn't right or fair that this is still happening - and it means people with eating disorders aren't getting the treatment they need to prevent them getting worse.After I came through my relapse I decided that I needed to help others, so I wrote a book, Stand Tall Little Girl, and I began doing talks about mental health.

title: senior mp calls for proper investigation into qatar world cup bid claims
story: Qatar said it "rejected" all of the allegations, while the international governing body FIFA said there had already been an investigation into Qatar's bid and no wrongdoing had been found.Reacting to the Sunday Times report, Mr Collins said: "I think what needs to happen now is for there to be a proper independent investigation of the allegations published in the Sunday Times."I've met the whistleblower myself and seen the evidence that he's brought forward."I think these are serious matters and there needs to be a proper independent investigation of them."Mr Collins added there had been a "big loss of confidence" in FIFA as a result of corruption allegations, and said the latest claims represent an "opportunity to demonstrate that FIFA takes these issues much more seriously than it has done". According to FIFA's rules, bidders must "refrain from making any written or oral statements of any kind, whether adverse or otherwise, about the bids or candidatures of any other member association which has expressed an interest in hosting and staging the competitions".The Qatar bid team has been accused of corruption before, but was cleared after a two-year investigation by FIFA's ethics committee.Qatar's Supreme Committee for Delivery and Legacy said in a statement: "The Supreme Committee rejects each and every allegation put forward by the Sunday Times."We have been thoroughly investigated and have been forthcoming with all information related to our bid, including the official investigation led by US attorney Michael Garcia."We have strictly adhered to all FIFA's rules and regulations for the 2018/2022 World Cup bidding process."

title: zara tindall reveals she had a second miscarriage
story: That pregnancy had been announced publicly just a month earlier, as is generally the rule for descendants of the Queen.She said: "We had to tell everyone and it's like, everyone knows - that's the hardest bit."That's why I think a lot of people don't talk about it because [a miscarriage] can happen early enough or it's only your group of friends and your family that know." She said the first miscarriage had been a case of "nature not working", adding: "In our case, it was something that was really rare it was nature saying, 'this one's not right', which your body does a lot, I think".She added: "Because it's so personal to each family and every case is different, you can never compare what's happened or the feelings that people have gone through or the trauma."Every case is different so I think it's something that people don't think you want to talk about."The Tindalls have two daughters, Mia, four, and Lena, who was born in June.

title: zimbabwe election president mnangagwas promises are questioned by opposition leader
story: Zimbabwe's president has plenty to gain from a convincing victory in terms of political legitimacy and the prospect of investment - but the leader of the largest opposition party, the MDC Alliance, does not buy this transformation.Speaking to Sky News, 40-year-old Nelson Chamisa told me: "Now he is saying that Zimbabwe is open for business. But who closed it 38 years ago?"Now he says there is a new dispensation, but who was a key player in the old dispensation? You know, he cannot pretend to be born again."At an MDC Alliance rally in a township outside the capital Harare, people were scathing about the president's democratic credentials. "Ha ha, real democracy, my foot, not Mnangagwa," said one man. "He was as the side kick on Mugabe. They were cronies for years."Nelson Chamisa told Sky News he is not scared and is prepared to resist if he thinks ZANU-PF has interfered in the result."We know that victory is ours, we have won this election. The MDC is the only game in town but if they cheat, if they try and rig it, we have plans afoot to defend our vote.""We will see violence and chaos?" I asked.

title: army standby deliver vital food
story: News'Army on standby' to deliver vital food and medicine in a No Deal BrexitTroops, helicopters and trucks could spring into action to move vital food, medicines and fuel if border controls break downShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByDan BloomPolitical reporter11:31, 29 JUL 2018Updated17:02, 29 JUL 2018NewsTroops, helicopters and trucks could spring into actionGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTory ministers are drawing up plans to send in the Army if there is a No Deal Brexit , it emerged today. Troops, helicopters and trucks could spring into action to move vital food, medicines and fuel if border controls break down. The shock report comes after ministers admitted they are considering the stockpiling of medicines and food supplies. Today leading doctors warned the treatment of thousands of cancer patients could be delayed, risking their lives, if there's no agreement by March 2019. Medical isotopes help around 10,000 patients a year but could become snarled up in border checks, experts warned the Mail on Sunday. Dr Jeanette Dickson, of the Royal College of Radiologists, said: These medicines are like a burning fuse.  They start off with a certain amount of radioactivity and you have a set time to get them to hospital when they are still effective. If you delay them for a fews hours, you begin to lost activity. Meanwhile supermarket giant Aldi reportedly emailed suppliers asking them to help understand potential implications and mitigate any negative impacts of No Deal. That prompted one anonymous coffee supplier to consider keeping up to eight weeks' stock instead of four, according to the Sunday Times. And a supermarket chairman told the newspaper: We're probably still a few months off, but there will come a point in this calendar year where, if people are going to book extra warehouse space or make additional transport arrangements, they will have to start doing it because there isn't unlimited capacity. Aldi has not commented on the reports.  Brexit talks remain in deadlock ahead of an October deadline, forcing the UK government to ramp up backup plans for No Deal. Imperial College London research in March claimed there would be 29-mile, five-hour tailbacks to Dover if the time to clear customs paperwork doubled from two minutes to just four. And plans are being considered to turn the M26 motorway - a key artery to the Kent port - could be turned into a 10-mile lorry park for 1,400 trucks.

title: labour mp ian austin accuses
story: NewsLabour MP Ian Austin accuses Jeremy Corbyn of 'supporting' anti-Semites as he faces discipline probeIan Austin claimed Labour is becoming a "much more extreme" party as he became the second MP to be investigated for attacks on the Labour leaderShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByDan BloomPolitical reporter14:58, 29 JUL 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA Labour MP has accused Jeremy Corbyn of supporting and defending anti-Semites after it emerged he is facing a disciplinary probe. Ian Austin claimed Labour is becoming a much more extreme party as he became the second MP to be investigated for attacks on the Labour leader. Party chiefs are probing the Dudley MP, a serial critic of the leadership, for abusive conduct after he confronted Labour chair Ian Lavery and branded action on anti-Semitism a bloody disgrace. Sources told the Mirror's Kevin Maguire he also called the shadow cabinet minister a f***ing b*****d and a w****r - claims Mr Austin denies.  It comes days after it emerged veteran MP Margaret Hodge is being probed for confronting Mr Corbyn and calling him an anti-Semite.  She was also accused of using the f-word, which she also denied.  Today Mr Austin, whose adoptive father fled the Holocaust, said he was upset about the leadership’s failure, I think refusal really, to deal with this properly. Mr Austin admitted his confrontation with Mr Lavery was “heated” but said “did I scream abuse at anybody? No I didn’t.” He BBC Radio 4's The World This Weekend: I’m really shocked that a party that’s got a proud tradition throughout its entire existence of fighting racism has ended up causing such huge offence and distress to the Jewish community in Britain. I think this could never have happened before.  “I’m appalled that it’s happened, I’m ashamed of the Labour Party , I really am.  “And I think if I’m honest we’re becoming a different political party - this could never have happened in the past.  Attacking Mr Corbyn, he added: He’s spent his entire time in politics on the extreme fringes of the Labour party supporting and defending all sorts of extremists and in some cases, frankly, anti-Semites. That’s why I thought three years ago he shouldn’t be the leader of the Labour Party and that’s why I think now that somebody with views and a history like his isn’t really suited to the leadership of a mainstream political party. “I was worried that what would happen is a mainstream social democratic party would be turned into something much more extreme. That’s what I fear is happening - that’s what I’m worried about. It comes amid an angry debate within Labour after the party failed to adopt the full International Holocaust Remembrance Alliance (IHRA) definition of anti-Semitism. Labour's code explicitly endorses the IHRA's working definition of anti-Semitism, but it omits four examples from the IHRA list.   Labour insisted that while the examples are not reproduced word for word, they are covered in the new code.  Shadow Justice Secretary Richard Burgon said he was not going to condemn Mr Austin because it is important that people who have strong opinions… can express themselves. He added: Jeremy doesn’t associate with the people who make the kind of extreme anti-Semitic comments that have been described on social media. It’s quite right that he doesn’t - he condemns them.” Some Labour MPs rallied behind Mr Austin today. Siobhain McDonagh called him a nice man, great MP adding: This is madness. Peter Kyle added: If the exchange reported is the one I witnessed, it was far from ‘abusive’. Labour will not solve the antisemitism problem it has by disciplining children of Jewish refugees like Ian Austin, but by listening to them. This cycle of madness must end.

title: theresa faces tory brexit revolt
story: NewsTheresa May faces Tory Brexit revolt as her own local party demands she cut ties with EUThe Prime Minister's own constituency chairman in Maidenhead is among those warning she must not concede any further ground to the EUShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAndrew GregoryPolitical EditorDan BloomPolitical reporter13:28, 29 JUL 2018NewsTheresa May attending church in her seat of Maidenhead - where local Tories aren't happy (Image: PA)Get politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Theresa May faces a Tory grassroots backlash over her blueprint for Brexit .  The Prime Minister has been warned by her own constituency chairman that she must not concede any further ground to the EU. Seven chairmen of Cabinet ministers’ Conservative associations today said they either oppose the plans in their current form or would withdraw their support if Mrs May offered any further concessions to Brussels. Richard Kellaway, the chairman of Mrs May’s Maidenhead Conservative association, said: “If it were to be diluted it would ultimately not be acceptable”. Lib Dem MP and Foreign Affairs spokesperson Christine Jardine warned that Brexit could be determined by Tory internal party fighting. She said: “Yet again we are hearing about internal party fighting that could determine the position of the Prime Minister. In the interests of the country, we must demand better.  “As long as the Tories are dominated by these massive internal divisions they simply cannot be trusted to do the right thing.”  It came as former Home Secretary Amber Rudd hit out with a vicious attack comparing Brexiteers in her own party to climate change deniers.  Trade Secretary Liam Fox famously claimed a post-Brexit trade deal with the EU would be one of the easiest in human history. But Ms Rudd wrote Brexit will not be straightforward, adding: Anyone who claims it will is being as cavalier with people's future as those who deny that the belching of fossil fuels into the atmosphere is warming the planet.  Just as we must listen to scientific warnings about the risks of manmade climate change, so we must listen to the businesses and economists warning a chaotic Brexit will threaten our economy. Meanwhile ex-Chancellor George Osborne warned the Tories are politically screwed if they do not reconnect with modern Britain. In an GQ interview the Hard Remainer claimed the 2016 referendum was a vote for hybrid membership with the EU - risking the fury of Brexiteers. He added Tory Leave-backers are being found out as they try and put off the actual effects of leaving for years to come. The growing Tory row came as Mrs May was also warned by Italy’s deputy Prime Minister to take a hard line with the EU over Brexit negotiations or risk being cheated.  Right-wing populist Matteo Salvini said Mrs May should be prepared to walk away without a deal, adding: “On some principles there is no need to be flexible and you should not go backwards.” Her white paper sparked the resignation of Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson and Brexit Secretary David Davis. Some Tories have backed it but warned it should be a line in the sand - not a starting point for negotiations.

story: NewsTheresa May's holiday snaps are even more boring than the mutual recognition of goods standards post-BrexitPhotos of the PM's Lake Garda stroll are even more anodyne than the walk she took last year, in exactly the same townShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByDan BloomPolitical reporter16:35, 29 JUL 2018Updated16:52, 29 JUL 2018NewsThrilling scenes just in from northern Italy (Image: Getty Images Europe)Get politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailShe's escaped deadlocked Brexit talks for an Italian getaway with husband Philip. title: top tory dominic raab reduced
story: NewsTop Tory Dominic Raab reduced staff member to tears by 'screaming' down the phone claims sacked diary secretaryRebecca Tott, 21, who was dismissed for leading a double life as an escort, said she "felt bullied". A source close to the Brexit Secretary branded the claims "false and malicious"Share&nbsp&nbspCommentsByDan BloomPolitical reporter12:31, 29 JUL 2018Updated17:22, 29 JUL 2018NewsTop Tory Dominic Raab left staff in tears by screaming down the phone, it is claimed (Image: PA)Get politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTop Tory Dominic Raab left a staff member in tears by screaming down the phone and flying into rages, his sacked secretary claims today. Rebecca Tott, 21, said she felt bullied by the Brexit Secretary after she was dismissed for leading a double life as an escort following a Daily Mirror expose. Ms Tott's allegations were vigorously denied today. The government said it did not recognise them - and a source close to Mr Raab branded them an attempt to cash in by smearing with false and malicious claims. We revealed in April how Ms Tott told an undercover reporter, posing as a wealthy &shybusinessman, that for &pound750 he could have “full undisputed access to me”. Mr Raab's then-diary secretary also accused the minister of having the same lunch from Pret a Manger each day - which he denied. Since then high-flier Mr Raab has been promoted from Housing Minister to Brexit Secretary. He now sits in the Cabinet and leads crucial talks with Brussels.  Meanwhile Ms Tott, also a high-flier who entered Whitehall as an apprentice, has been dismissed from her job, a government source confirmed. Today Ms Tott spoke out about Mr Raab's alleged behaviour in her first interview since being sacked. She claimed he had the nasty tendency not to admit he was wrong, hit the roof over a diary mixup and demanded he was driven the seven-minute walk from his Whitehall office to Parliament. There were days he would call other staff to scream at them down the phone, she told the Sun on Sunday. It reduced one of my colleagues to tears. He called her later to say 'sorry, I was overworked and over-stressed.  Ms Tott claimed Mr Raab complained at having five minutes cut out of his gym regime and used an aggressive and patronising tone. I felt it was impossible to work with him, she said. The way he spoke to others was short and sharp. He'd cut people off. She added: No woman should have to go through it again. It was an outright abuse of power. The Mirror did not name Ms Tott in our initial investigation. However, she was later named by other newspapers before giving today's interview. Brexiteer and karate black belt Mr Raab, 44, has enjoyed a controversial rise to power since being elected MP for Esher and Walton in 2010. He sparked fury last year by saying most food bank users are not languishing in poverty, and when a disability activist told him people are dying under Tory austerity, he described her calls for cash as a childish wish list.  He also put out a pamphlet in 2011 that suggested exempting small firms from minimum wage laws for workers under 21. In the same year he said feminists are now amongst the most obnoxious bigots and said it was time for men to start burning their briefs. Today junior housing minister Rishi Sunak insisted Mr Raab was a great colleague, supportive and collegiate and I have tremendous respect for him. A Housing Ministry spokesman said: We do not recognise these claims and they do not reflect the department's experience - including those who worked directly with the minister in his private office.

title: bus driver stalked infatuated passenger
story: NewsBus driver stalked by infatuated passenger for SIX years now lives in fear and wears stab-proof vest every dayEXCLUSIVE: Imre Marton is so scared he lives like a recluse and covers the windows of his home with opaque film and thick black curtains so no one can see inShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByRosa McMahon21:45, 28 JUL 2018Updated08:02, 29 JUL 2018NewsImre Marton says he never feels safe (Image: PA Real Life)Get daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA bus driver stalked by an &shyinfatuated passenger for six years has told of how he now wears a stab-proof vest every day in fear that she will make good on her threats to kill him. Imre Marton, 33, is so scared he lives like a recluse. He covers the windows of his home with film and thick black &shycurtains so no one can see in. And his ordeal goes on despite his tormentor Charlie Howells being behind bars for a second time because she has &shysuggested she has accomplices ready to help her and his “days are numbered”. Imre said: “I never feel safe. I know she won’t stop and this is never going to end. I am living in fear, always looking over my shoulder. I am sure that one day she will kill me. It’s the end goal for her. Her mission is for us to die together,” Imre’s nightmare began in 2012 when Howells, 24, first boarded his No32 bus in Oxfordshire. She began memorising his schedules. Her bizarre &shybehaviour &shyincluded standing just inches behind him so she could sniff him.  After she declared her love for Imre and he rejected her, Howells began &shybombarding him with thousands of &shymessages – &shysometimes up to 500 a day. They included proposals, suggesting they tie the knot on a bus, and claims she had found his home address. Imre reported her and after four years of &shytorment she got two years in May 2016. He spoke to the Sunday People after the case and in November 2017 took part in BBC documentary My Stalker and Me to help raise awareness of the issue. But his appearance re-ignited Howells’s campaign and she messaged him on Facebook to say: “You are the biggest fool ever, going on TV saying you wear a stab vest.  Well now Charlie knows where not to stab you… You thought your life was in danger then, there are many people out to get you now. I’d watch my back if I was you, you have been warned!!!!” Earlier this month Howells was jailed again for three years at Oxford crown court and given a ten-year restraining order. Imre, who left the city in January but is too scared to say where he is, said: “I take no comfort in her getting three years. “It just gives her more time to plan what she is going to do next – and that terrifies me.” Recalling how the campaign started, he said: “I’d feel her breath on me. She was like a ninja, she would &shyappear from nowhere. She was always there.” After his rejection, Howells began turning up in shops and cafes Imre was visiting. On the bus she played One Direction songs and handed him notes.  Police gave Howells a &shywarning but she found Imre on Facebook. He was forced to delete his account and apply for a transfer out of the city centre. Howells found him again and in August 2014 he won a two-year &shyrestraining order – &shybanning her from the city, his route and any contact. She ignored it. Imre said: “To avoid her, I cut my bus shifts and began working as a bouncer but she found me, getting my number from a driver who didn’t know how dangerous she was. She called every minute of the day.” Imre called 101 or 999 every time but her stalking campaign escalated. In 2015 Howells first said she was going to kill him – running a finger across her throat as she made the threat. Terrifingly, in April that year, Imre was with a colleague when Howells threw water in his face which he feared was acid. He said: “I felt lucky it was only water but it made me realise how easy it was for her to harm me.” In August, with Howells screaming “like an animal” at him, he called police again. She was remanded in custody and Imre secured a two-year restraining order. Howells was then twice convicted of breaching her restraining order and jailed in June 2015 for eight weeks. After persistently ignoring the order, she got two years in May 2016. The order was extended to five years.  But even with Howells behind bars, Imre was not safe. The first message he got was from a “friend” of hers, who Imre believes was a fake account. She continued to declare her love for him when she was released in August last year. Despite Imre blocking Howells, she kept creating new accounts. After he &shyappeared in the documentary, her messages took an even more sinister turn. Chillingly, Howells told Imre: “If I can’t have you, no one else will.” She also told him on the bus and in the street that they were “going to die together”. The stalking escalated and in January Howells, of Shrivenham, Oxon, was held again after turning up at a bus stop and shouting and screaming at him. Police found she had a blade. Imre said: “I felt scared. I was told she was saying she is going to stab me in the neck and she had a knife.” He took a lower-paid job, which he does not wish to reveal, and left Oxford. He did not go to court on July 5 to see her locked up again. Imre said: “Even though she is behind bars again, I am still in constant fear. Everywhere I look, I think of her. She’s ruined my life.” Howells got three years after admitting breaching a restraining order, intimidating a witness and possessing a bladed article. But Imre said the term “is not long enough” and his own life is now more like serving a sentence.

title: 8 secrets building your childs
story: Advertorial8 secrets to building your child's confidence cycling on the roadIt's a big step up so follow this advice for a safe rideShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByDave Masters12:13, 25 JUL 2018Updated14:46, 29 JUL 2018AdvertorialGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailCycling on the road is an important skill for young cyclists to learn. But before your kids will be happy riding on the road they'll need to have some practice. This might include tarmac-surfaced bike paths or very quiet roads. But as they get better on two wheels you'll want to help them get used to road cycling to prepare them for when they're ready to venture out alone. 1. First thing to do: get their bike checked  Before you set out on any bike ride, make sure everything is in good shape for the ride ahead.  Halfords offer a Free Bike Check , giving you complete confidence without having to get your hands dirty. In-store experts will check tyre pressure, brakes and gears. If they spot anything that needs attention, they can fix it too.   2. Start traffic-free   One way to get started cycling on the road is to follow a national bike route and take a small diversion.  Sustrans , the cycling charity, has loads of great family rides that are either entirely traffic-free, or mostly. But if you want to give little ones a quiet road to practice on then you can always find one along the way.  Because these routes are also shared with pedestrians this gives you a chance to educate your little ones on being considerate and safe. Explain that they should stay on one side, not zig-zag across the whole path. Treat these paths like a road and make it into a fun game that helps your kids learn.  3. Pick the right bike   Hybrid bikes take elements from road bikes and mountain bikes, so they are a great choice if you are looking for something that's great on the roads but also suitable for some slightly rougher terrain.  A good option for younger cyclists is the Apollo Vortice Junior Hybrid Bike (above), &pound120 (save &pound10) which offers 18 gears with twist shifters for easy gear changes. Plus you get &pound15 worth of free accessories when you buy a junior bike at Halfords right now.    Of course, it's equally important to invest in a good bike for yourself. The Carrera Subway 1 Hybrid Bike (above) is &pound300 and ideal for mums and dads looking to head out on their own on an equally good set of wheels. Thanks to its lightweight frame and 24 gears, you’ll be able to tackle hills no problem, without fear that your kids will show you up!  With frames ranging from 14 to 22 inches, it's perfect for adults and teenagers alike. Disc brakes mean great stopping performance too.   If you are looking to upgrade your current bike then the Boardman MTX 8.6 Hybrid Bike (above) is is great and priced at &pound500. It has you covered from road to trails with it's versatile design. The aluminium frame is light to save weight, paired with the Suntour NEX forks that are designed to give you complete control over mountainous terrain while off-roading.  Better still, Halfords are currently offering &pound75 of free accessories and clothing when you buy any 8 Series Boardman Bike.  4. Keep the kids in tow            The other step you could take to get younger kids used to on-road cycling is to use a trail gator. Essentially a tow bar that connects a small bike to yours via a rigid metal bar. These mean that your children can be towed on the road by you, getting them used to the traffic in a safe manner.   They can pedal along and the Trail Gator (above) which is now &pound40.04 (save &pound29.95) keeps their front wheel above the road, meaning they can't cause problems by steering (but can still move the handlebars like mum or dad).   5. Use a good roadside bike route         Once your little one starts gaining confidence, head to a good local cycle lane that's close to a road. This is a good way of introducing your youngsters to the noise of the road and the movement of the cars. It also keeps them somewhat separate from other road users.  Routes like Manchester's Medlock Valley have a selection of different paths and road routes that might help to ease new riders into being confident on the road. Check Sustrans for local rides to you.  Once your kids are able to cycle in a straight line (roughly at least) and avoid obstacles without panicking then they'll feel a lot more confident about hopping on the roads.  The Carrera Subway Junior Hybrid Bike (above) priced &pound208 (save &pound52) will help your child get out and about in no time at all. It has a lightweight junior fit aluminium hybrid frame for a light and easy ride, complete with 21 speed Shimano Revoshift gears for slick shifting.   6. Helmets are a must         A well fitting helmet can seriously reduce the risk of a head injury, so you should get your kids in the habit of wearing one whenever they are out on their bikes. Feel free to let your kids pick a helmet that suits their personality. That way there will be no arguments when it comes to popping it on.  Halfords stock a range of fun helmets starting at &pound10. Designs like the Paw Patrol Kids Bike Helmet (&pound20), Disney Princess Helmet (&pound20) and stylish Blogger Junior Bike Helmet (above) priced &pound17 are among the most popular.  This colourful helmet has a comfy fit thanks to its removable pads and clever dial-fit adjustment system, and is topped off with plenty of vents to keep heads cool.  Adults will want to stay cool with the ventilated Boardman LC 8.6 Helmet , &pound28, save &pound12. The visor keeps weather out of your eyes and its nice and light for long ride comfort.  If you're not sure where to start, pop into your local Halfords and our friendly experts will help find the right helmet for you and your family.  7. Riding on the pavement - what the law says    It's technically illegal to ride a bike on the pavement. However, the advice given to police is to be sensitive to circumstances.  While they can theoretically stop young children (aged under 10) who are cycling on pavements, they have no powers to arrest, fine or even caution them. This is sensible, as young children should not be expected to cycle on the road. (source: cyclinguk.org )  Police are allowed to use their discretion - so adults, too, can get a pass for pavement cycling if there's a reason for example, cycling with your kids.  If you're on the lookout for your child's first bike, right now the Carrera Cosmos Kids Bike (below) is priced at&pound128 (save &pound32).   Ideal for kids who are confident enough to ride without stabilisers, the Carrera Cosmos Kids Bike has an aluminium frame, making it easy to manoeuvre, as well as genuine Kenda tyres and alloy V-brakes.

title: adoptive mother child who lost
story: NewsAdoptive mother of child who lost legs after brutal attack by biological parents says they should 'rot in prison'EXCLUSIVE: Paula Hudgell is calling for a law change to make sure child attackers serve their full sentences after what happened to Tony when he was five months oldShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByScarlet HowesJulia Roberts22:20, 28 JUL 2018Updated22:22, 28 JUL 2018NewsTony Hudgell and his adoptive mother Paula (Image: Steve Bainbridge/Sunday People)Get daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBrave little Tony Hudgell is the picture of happiness but his beaming smile masks the tot’s horrific start to life. As the three-year-old poses on his &shyloving adopted mum’s lap, few would realise the hell he has endured. Tony was just six weeks old when his parents violently swung him around by the legs, causing eight fractures. He was injured so badly that he had to have a double amputation.  But mum Jody Simpson and dad Tony Smith were only brought to &shyjustice because of the determination of his adoptive mum Paula Hudgell. And Paula is still fighting for justice after Simpson, 24, and Smith, 47, were convicted of child cruelty and jailed for ten years. Paula, 50, is campaigning for &shytougher sentences for child neglect and abuse. And she has spoken out after Simpson made a bid to be freed early from jail. She said: “Jody left her son close to death and now she wants sympathy. She can’t accept her guilt for what she did to her own child. “By appealing to have her sentence reduced shows she has no remorse.” She added: “Both his parents &shydeserve to rot in prison.” Tony was just 41 days old when he was admitted to hospital with multiple organ failure, numerous &shyfractures and sepsis.  By four months, he still weighed only 9lb 7oz but he was ready to be &shydischarged into the arms of foster&shy &shycarers Paula and Mark, 53 – who have seven kids of their own. Paula first met Tony in February 2015. She said: “Tony was on the brink of death. My heart broke.” Tony’s body had inflated like a &shyballoon fighting infections from thigh bone, lower leg, ankle, thumb, and toe fractures. Doctors said he may never be able to sit up or crawl and may face development delays from the amount of life-saving drugs he received. Paula knew little about Tony’s &shybackground but alarm bells rang after meeting his birth parents, who told her the injuries had been a “terrible accident”. Paula and asset manager Mark took Tony home in Kings Hill, Kent, to meet their children Ben, 28, Chloe, 23, Ryan, 26, Kyle, 16, Jessica, 11, Jaden, ten, and Lacey, five.  Paula, a former market researcher, said: “I didn’t think too much about his parents – we were all just getting to grips with Tony’s medical needs. “But my stomach churned when it was time for his first supervised visit with his mum and dad. “His dad came bounding up, saying, ‘Thanks for looking after our boy. You’ll think us bad parents but it was just a terrible accident’. I couldn’t shake off the suspicion it was more than that.” In May 2015, Paula and Mark told social services they wanted to adopt him. A year later, he was legally theirs. Paula went straight to the police to voice her concerns but was told there was “insufficient evidence” to prove any abuse by Tony’s parents. She said: “I knew detectives were looking into the case but I had no right to information until I was Tony’s legal parent. “As soon as the adoption came through I contacted them and heard it had been dropped.  “I was devastated. I wrote a victim’s right to appeal letter to the CPS. Within weeks, a detective came to see me to explain why it hadn’t gone to court. I told them about my meeting with Tony’s real dad and what he’d said. He was shocked. He said there and then that he would re-look at the case.” Smith and Simpson were charged months later. They denied causing physical harm and cruelty to Tony. They told police they delayed taking Tony for medical help because they were waiting in for a plumber. Paula faced the pair in Maidstone Crown Court in February. She said: “I was terrified. But I’m a mum and you do anything for your child.” After the verdict, the judge told the court: “Tony’s adoptive family are stars. They are absolute stars.” Tony will be four in October and is learning to use prosthetic limbs, which he got just before Christmas last year.  Paula said: “He will never recover fully. Everything he does, he has to adapt to his own way. “Now he has stubbies – to try and help him use prosthetics in the future. He doesn’t like wearing them as they do restrict him. It’s a lot of hard work. “But he’s so happy. He took his first swim stroke without an arm band last weekend. We went on a day out to Peppa Pig World and stayed the night. “I was so proud as it was a huge achievement for him. He absolutely loves life at the moment.” Paula said Tony loves sport and is &shytaking tennis lessons. She also has a positive outlook on Tony’s lifelong disability. She said: “The absence of his legs will not be a lifelong &shyreminder of his parents’ cruelty. “It will be a reminder of what an incredible human being he is. He is a lovely boy and I am so proud to call him my son.

title: asda shopper who saved baby
story: NewsAsda shopper who saved baby left in baking car says 'guards wouldn't help over fears of losing their job'Jenna Langston, 33, raced to help the three-month-old infant when she saw the baby left alone in a car at an Asda store in Barnes HillShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByJames Cartledge18:32, 29 JUL 2018Updated18:50, 29 JUL 2018NewsHero Asda shopper Jenna Langston saved a baby from a sweltering hot car after seeing the baby had been left alone in the car parkGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn Asda shopper who saved a baby left alone in a car in 30C heat claims a security guard wouldn't help her as he was worried about losing his job. Jenna Langston, 33, spotted the infant in the baking hot car and raced to help him by forcing open the boat and then opening the doors from the inside. The little boy was soaked in sweat and had been left alone in the car for at least half an hour before Jenna arrived on the scene at the Asda store in Barnes Hill. Emergency services rushed to the supermarket and the baby was taken to hospital. Jenna, who works as a care manager, was at the store to buy her favourite egg custards when she saw the baby, believed to be just three months old, in the back of the car.   She told Birmingham Live : I saw a guard standing by a black car and initially thought: 'I hope no-one's left a dog in there.'  I had already heard a tannoy announcement giving a registration plate while I was inside the store and quite a bit of time had passed since then. But a guard said a baby was inside. I dropped my shopping and ran over to the car. I said the baby needed to come out straight away - it was 31C. But the guard said they couldn't break in because it would be classed as breaking and entering. I said I didn't care and I was going to get the baby out. The guard said: 'We can't help you do that. I could lose my job.' All the doors were locked and none of the windows were open. I forced the boot and threw bags and everything else out to get access to the baby. I got myself into the boot and put my top half over the back seat. He was dripping with sweat - his babygrow was like it had been through the washing machine. I opened the doors to let some air in and someone else asked if I wanted to sit in their car with the baby as it had air conditioning. Then the police and paramedics arrived. I handed the baby over to the ambulance crew. They said he seemed fine but they had to take him to hospital. There was still no sign of the car driver - it had been around 50 minutes by now. Then she appeared, walking slowly back to her car.

story: NewsFamily's nightmare as street light is suddenly installed outside their door - glaring through daughter's bedroom windowWhen they moved into the £600,000 house in Newton Mearns, near Glasgow, there was no street light, but workers have erected one sinceShare&nbspByMirror09:34, 29 JUL 2018NewsAngry Lay Khoo with her daughters at the lamppost that's blighting their lives (Image: Robert Perry)Get daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum says her daughter can't sleep at night after a street light was installed right outside their front door.
